htmlEmbed:
OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent Is Haunting My BrowserReece Rogers7/22/2025

New tools from OpenAI and Perplexity can browse the web for you. If the idea takes off, these generative AI agents could turn the internet into a ghost town where only bots roam.

gear, trends, artificial intelligence, openai, browsers, chatgpt, chatbots, splitscreenimagerightinset, web, tagsRead

        </script><script type="text/javascript">window.cns = window.cns || {}; window.cns.pageContext = {"channel":"gear","content":{"copyCount":1011,"imageCount":0,"embedCount":2,"ratio":505.5,"midContentCadence":500},"contentType":"article","experiments":{},"keywords":{"copilotid":["687e8b75dc6d071e90252da5"],"platform":["verso"],"tags":["artificial-intelligence","openai","browsers","chatgpt","chatbots","gear","trends"]},"targeting":{"feature_flags":[]},"server":"production","slug":"browser-haunted-by-ai-agents","subChannel":"trends","subSubChannel":"","templateType":"mt_article_two_column"};</script><link rel="preconnect" href="https://ads-static.conde.digital"/><script id="ads-v6" src="https://ads-static.conde.digital/production/cns/builds/wired/v6.js" async=""></script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"I have four instances of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent—the generative AI tool released last week, which can run searches and perform tasks on the web—already open with each running in its own tab. I’ve given these first four agents relatively simple jobs based on ChatGPT’s suggestions. One is clicking around to find a birthday gift on the Target website, and another is generating a pitch deck about robotic dogs. I open a fifth tab in order to try something more experimental: I want to see how good this ChatGPT Agent is at chess.\nAfter typing in some instructions, I watch as a ghostly cursor floats across my screen and the ChatGPT Agent goes to Chess.com and plays an online opponent, all in a virtual browser. Things go south pretty quickly. The game's strategy isn't what trips up the AI tool, it's the act of moving the chess pieces that actually proves to be the most difficult. “I'm focusing on accurate positioning as I continue playing despite earlier misclicks,” the agent says in its internal log before eventually quitting and letting me know that the controls were too difficult to navigate.\nOver the past few years, browser developers have integrated AI tools with middling success. Though, in recent weeks, the idea of a web browser enhanced by a baked-in generative AI chatbot has resurged with the release of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent and Perplexity’s Comet.\nThe two releases are quite different in their execution. Comet is a stand-alone browser, so you can use it to surf the web and then summon the AI assistant to help write an email or complete a menial chore. OpenAI built its browsing tool inside of a chatbot; you talk to the chatbot through a web interface to give it tasks, and then the bot runs its own virtual browser inside your browser to complete them.\nBoth releases can take control of cursors, enter text, and click on links. If this trend takes off, these kinds of AI-powered browsers could transform the internet into a ghost town where agents run amok and humans rarely venture.\nTangled Web\nDespite the continued AI hype, my initial impression of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent is that the glitchy feature currently seems like a proof of concept instead of a fully baked release. When executing the various tasks I gave it, the ChatGPT Agent often clicked wrong or fumbled through other errors. Additionally, its guardrails appeared inconsistent; while some explicit prompt requests, like asking it to fetch pornographic videos or “find a dildo,” were denied by the agent, ChatGPT spent 18 minutes shopping for the perfect “c-ring” on an X-rated website for adult toys: “I've gathered details on 10 metal cock rings, including various prices and features.”\nI also couldn’t help but wonder how this approach to browsing the internet might further hollow out the market for digital display ads, a business that’s already struggling. My agents passed over ads for everything from rental cars to real estate investments. If you’re not actively watching the agent click around in real time, you can watch replays afterward and see everything that appeared in the browser while the AI tool was in control, ads included. It makes sense that users would speed-scrub through a replay now, while the nascent feature is filled with errors. But if the accuracy rate for AI agents improves over time, then fewer people will feel the need to watch over their agent’s shoulder, and fewer humans will be seeing those ads. At that point, it's hard to imagine advertisers sticking around.\nThe more I watched replays of its actions, the more the agent gave me an unsettling, eerie feeling—not of being understood, but of being mimicked. It was like an obsessive robot stalker had watched humans through a window, meticulously taking notes about how they used the web in an effort to replicate their actions. It was able to do a hollow imitation of human behavior, but not able to grasp fully why individual decisions were being made. The skin of my arms filled with the kind of goosebumps you get hearing a human-like laugh while walking home alone late at night, looking around, and only seeing a lone crow perched high up on the telephone wire.\nFurther leaning into the psuedo-humanness, the ChatGPT Agent is programmed to generate descriptions, from a first-person perspective, of each step on its journeys around the internet. While clicking, the simulation “thinks” and sometimes gets “confused.” As a whole, the ghostly agent is stuffed into an ill-fitting human suit.\nRunning five OpenAI agents simultaneously in my browser quickly became overwhelming, and I couldn’t actively track what each of them was up to. Yet, boosters of generative AI adoption and “multi-agent orchestration” see this kind of approach as child’s play.\n“I’m excited by simulation tech where 20,000 AIs are all working alongside each other,” says Allie K. Miller, an AI-focused business consultant. Miller’s approach to AI agents is more aligned with Silent Hill—and its fully haunted ghost town—than a small-scale haunting like The Conjuring.\nThis grandiose vision of the agentic future upheld by AI proponents—thousands of phantom bots swarming the web at once, all at the direction of a single person—still feels a long way off. My artisanal quintet of agents struggled with the handful of tasks I gave them, even when the prompts were just the ones suggested by ChatGPT. The agent I sent off in search of a birthday gift clicked on the wrong thing multiple times, similar to the chess-playing agent that couldn’t click on the right game piece. The agent generating a pitch deck took 26 minutes to gin up a presentation, and the results looked rushed, like something a struggling middle schooler would create the night before an assignment was due.\nTaking forever to generate mid results? Now that’s what I call a spooky story.","isBasedOn":"https://www.wired.com/story/browser-haunted-by-ai-agents/","articleSection":"gear","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Reece Rogers","sameAs":"https://www.wired.com/author/reece-rogers/"}],"dateModified":"2025-07-22T06:30:00.000-04:00","datePublished":"2025-07-22T06:30:00.000-04:00","headline":"OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent Is Haunting My Browser","image":["https://media.wired.com/photos/687eec8e56c21416a9856a2b/16:9/w_2400,h_1350,c_limit/ai-browser-ghost-gear-2160886749.jpg","https://media.wired.com/photos/687eec8e56c21416a9856a2b/4:3/w_2400,h_1800,c_limit/ai-browser-ghost-gear-2160886749.jpg","https://media.wired.com/photos/687eec8e56c21416a9856a2b/1:1/w_2400,h_2400,c_limit/ai-browser-ghost-gear-2160886749.jpg"],"keywords":["gear","trends","artificial intelligence","openai","browsers","chatgpt","chatbots","splitscreenimagerightinset","web"],"thumbnailUrl":"https://media.wired.com/photos/687eec8e56c21416a9856a2b/2:3/w_1600,h_2400,c_limit/ai-browser-ghost-gear-2160886749.jpg","url":"https://www.wired.com/story/browser-haunted-by-ai-agents/","isPartOf":{"@type":"CreativeWork","name":"WIRED"},"isAccessibleForFree":true,"alternativeHeadline":"New tools from OpenAI and Perplexity can browse the web for you. cxzKYj grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hkPQhP bKWPrI grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-beYvyV kCPYUp grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kzyFNv fWMjqR body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><figure class="CneAudioEmbedFigure-bWHoMv hIHLrt"><div><div id="js-audioembed-fpy1fh"></div></div></figure><p class="paywall"><span class="lead-in-text-callout">Most people’s browser</span> tabs are filled with unread news articles. Mine are filled with AI agents and ghost clicks.</p><p class="paywall">I have four instances of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent—the generative AI tool <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/openai-chatgpt-agent-launch/">released last week</a>, which can run searches and perform tasks on the web—already open with each running in its own tab. I’ve given these first four agents relatively simple jobs based on ChatGPT’s suggestions. One is clicking around to find a birthday gift on the Target website, and another is generating a pitch deck about robotic dogs. I open a fifth tab in order to try something more experimental: I want to see how good this ChatGPT Agent is at chess.</p><div class="AdWrapper-efOWgS iJRxsW ad ad--in-content"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--in-content" data-node-id="r1quhh"></div></div><p class="paywall">After typing in some instructions, I watch as a ghostly cursor floats across my screen and the ChatGPT Agent goes to <a data-offer-url="https://www.chess.com" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.chess.com"}" href="https://www.chess.com" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Chess.com</a> and plays an online opponent, all in a virtual browser. Things go south pretty quickly. The game's strategy isn't what trips up the AI tool, it's the act of moving the chess pieces that actually proves to be the most difficult. “I'm focusing on accurate positioning as I continue playing despite earlier misclicks,” the agent says in its internal log before eventually quitting and letting me know that the controls were too difficult to navigate.</p><div class="Container-VgtPr ekoLDG"></div><p class="paywall">Over the past few years, <a href="https://www.wired.com/tag/browsers/">browser</a> developers have <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/alternative-browsers-built-in-ai-arc-sigmaos-brave-opera/">integrated AI tools</a> with middling success. Though, in recent weeks, the idea of a web browser enhanced by a baked-in generative AI chatbot has resurged with the release of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent and <a data-offer-url="https://www.perplexity.ai/hub/blog/introducing-comet" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.perplexity.ai/hub/blog/introducing-comet"}" href="https://www.perplexity.ai/hub/blog/introducing-comet" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Perplexity’s Comet</a>.</p><div></div><div></div><p class="paywall">The two releases are quite different in their execution. Comet is a stand-alone browser, so you can use it to surf the web and then summon the AI assistant to help write an email or complete a menial chore. OpenAI built its browsing tool inside of a chatbot; you talk to the chatbot through a web interface to give it tasks, and then the bot runs its own virtual browser inside your browser to complete them.</p><div><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-jkpAEW hssEkF consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--article-mid-content" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--article-mid-content consumer-marketing-unit__slot--in-content"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div></div><p class="paywall">Both releases can take control of cursors, enter text, and click on links. If this trend takes off, these kinds of AI-powered browsers could transform the <a href="https://www.wired.com/tag/internet/">internet</a> into a ghost town where agents run amok and humans rarely venture.</p><h2 class="paywall">Tangled Web</h2><p class="paywall">Despite the continued <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/artificial-intelligence-hype-ai-snake-oil/">AI hype</a>, my initial impression of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent is that the glitchy feature currently seems like a proof of concept instead of a fully baked release. When executing the various tasks I gave it, the ChatGPT Agent often clicked wrong or fumbled through other errors. Additionally, its guardrails appeared inconsistent; while some explicit prompt requests, like asking it to fetch pornographic videos or “find a dildo,” were denied by the agent, ChatGPT spent 18 minutes shopping for the perfect “c-ring” on an X-rated website for adult toys: “I've gathered details on 10 metal cock rings, including various prices and features.”</p><p class="paywall">I also couldn’t help but wonder how this approach to browsing the internet might further hollow out the market for digital display ads, a business that’s already struggling. My agents passed over ads for everything from rental cars to real estate investments. If you’re not actively watching the agent click around in real time, you can watch replays afterward and see everything that appeared in the browser while the AI tool was in control, ads included. It makes sense that users would speed-scrub through a replay now, while the nascent feature is filled with errors. But if the accuracy rate for AI agents improves over time, then fewer people will feel the need to watch over their agent’s shoulder, and fewer humans will be seeing those ads. At that point, it's hard to imagine advertisers sticking around.</p></div></div></div></div><div data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gzmcOU RowWrapper-EQDhp deqABF fWZsjA full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-ghXnic hHUoRq ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-efOWgS iJRxsW ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="zd540m"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cFSKbf cxzKYj grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hkPQhP bKWPrI grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-beYvyV kCPYUp grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kzyFNv fWMjqR body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">The more I watched replays of its actions, the more the agent gave me an unsettling, eerie feeling—not of being understood, but of being mimicked. It was like an obsessive robot stalker had watched humans through a window, meticulously taking notes about how they used the web in an effort to replicate their actions. It was able to do a hollow imitation of human behavior, but not able to grasp fully why individual decisions were being made. The skin of my arms filled with the kind of goosebumps you get hearing a human-like laugh while walking home alone late at night, looking around, and only seeing a lone crow perched high up on the telephone wire.</p><div class="AdWrapper-efOWgS iJRxsW ad ad--sponsor-product"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--sponsor-product" data-node-id="zo7qo"></div></div><p class="paywall">Further leaning into the psuedo-humanness, the ChatGPT Agent is programmed to generate descriptions, from a first-person perspective, of each step on its journeys around the internet. While clicking, the simulation “thinks” and sometimes gets “confused.” As a whole, the ghostly agent is stuffed into an ill-fitting human suit.</p><p class="paywall">Running five OpenAI agents simultaneously in my browser quickly became overwhelming, and I couldn’t actively track what each of them was up to. Yet, boosters of generative AI adoption and “multi-agent orchestration” see this kind of approach as child’s play.</p><p class="paywall">“I’m excited by simulation tech where 20,000 AIs are all working alongside each other,” says Allie K. Miller, an AI-focused business consultant. Miller’s approach to AI agents is more aligned with <em>Silent Hill</em>—and its fully haunted ghost town—than a small-scale haunting like <em>The Conjuring</em>.</p><p class="paywall">This grandiose vision of the agentic future upheld by AI proponents—thousands of phantom bots swarming the web at once, all at the direction of a single person—still feels a long way off. My artisanal quintet of agents struggled with the handful of tasks I gave them, even when the prompts were just the ones suggested by ChatGPT. The agent I sent off in search of a birthday gift clicked on the wrong thing multiple times, similar to the chess-playing agent that couldn’t click on the right game piece. The agent generating a pitch deck took 26 minutes to gin up a presentation, and the results looked rushed, like something a struggling middle schooler would create the night before an assignment was due.</p><p class="paywall">Taking forever to generate mid results? Now that’s what I call a spooky story.</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cFSKbf cxzKYj grid grid-margins grid-items-2 PaywallInlineBarrierWithWrapperGrid-fiVSub fvfXGr If the idea takes off, these generative AI agents could turn the internet into a ghost town where only bots roam.","head.promo.dek":"New tools from OpenAI and Perplexity can browse the web for you. If the idea takes off, these generative AI agents could turn the internet into a ghost town where only bots roam.","head.social.opinion":"false","head.jsonld":[{"@context":"http:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"I have four instances of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent—the generative AI tool released last week, which can run searches and perform tasks on the web—already open with each running in its own tab. I’ve given these first four agents relatively simple jobs based on ChatGPT’s suggestions. One is clicking around to find a birthday gift on the Target website, and another is generating a pitch deck about robotic dogs. I open a fifth tab in order to try something more experimental: I want to see how good this ChatGPT Agent is at chess.\nAfter typing in some instructions, I watch as a ghostly cursor floats across my screen and the ChatGPT Agent goes to Chess.com and plays an online opponent, all in a virtual browser. Things go south pretty quickly. The game's strategy isn't what trips up the AI tool, it's the act of moving the chess pieces that actually proves to be the most difficult. “I'm focusing on accurate positioning as I continue playing despite earlier misclicks,” the agent says in its internal log before eventually quitting and letting me know that the controls were too difficult to navigate.\nOver the past few years, browser developers have integrated AI tools with middling success. Though, in recent weeks, the idea of a web browser enhanced by a baked-in generative AI chatbot has resurged with the release of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent and Perplexity’s Comet.\nThe two releases are quite different in their execution. Comet is a stand-alone browser, so you can use it to surf the web and then summon the AI assistant to help write an email or complete a menial chore. OpenAI built its browsing tool inside of a chatbot; you talk to the chatbot through a web interface to give it tasks, and then the bot runs its own virtual browser inside your browser to complete them.\nBoth releases can take control of cursors, enter text, and click on links. If this trend takes off, these kinds of AI-powered browsers could transform the internet into a ghost town where agents run amok and humans rarely venture.\nTangled Web\nDespite the continued AI hype, my initial impression of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent is that the glitchy feature currently seems like a proof of concept instead of a fully baked release. When executing the various tasks I gave it, the ChatGPT Agent often clicked wrong or fumbled through other errors. Additionally, its guardrails appeared inconsistent; while some explicit prompt requests, like asking it to fetch pornographic videos or “find a dildo,” were denied by the agent, ChatGPT spent 18 minutes shopping for the perfect “c-ring” on an X-rated website for adult toys: “I've gathered details on 10 metal cock rings, including various prices and features.”\nI also couldn’t help but wonder how this approach to browsing the internet might further hollow out the market for digital display ads, a business that’s already struggling. My agents passed over ads for everything from rental cars to real estate investments. If you’re not actively watching the agent click around in real time, you can watch replays afterward and see everything that appeared in the browser while the AI tool was in control, ads included. It makes sense that users would speed-scrub through a replay now, while the nascent feature is filled with errors. But if the accuracy rate for AI agents improves over time, then fewer people will feel the need to watch over their agent’s shoulder, and fewer humans will be seeing those ads. At that point, it's hard to imagine advertisers sticking around.\nThe more I watched replays of its actions, the more the agent gave me an unsettling, eerie feeling—not of being understood, but of being mimicked. It was like an obsessive robot stalker had watched humans through a window, meticulously taking notes about how they used the web in an effort to replicate their actions. It was able to do a hollow imitation of human behavior, but not able to grasp fully why individual decisions were being made. The skin of my arms filled with the kind of goosebumps you get hearing a human-like laugh while walking home alone late at night, looking around, and only seeing a lone crow perched high up on the telephone wire.\nFurther leaning into the psuedo-humanness, the ChatGPT Agent is programmed to generate descriptions, from a first-person perspective, of each step on its journeys around the internet. While clicking, the simulation “thinks” and sometimes gets “confused.” As a whole, the ghostly agent is stuffed into an ill-fitting human suit.\nRunning five OpenAI agents simultaneously in my browser quickly became overwhelming, and I couldn’t actively track what each of them was up to. Yet, boosters of generative AI adoption and “multi-agent orchestration” see this kind of approach as child’s play.\n“I’m excited by simulation tech where 20,000 AIs are all working alongside each other,” says Allie K. Miller, an AI-focused business consultant. Miller’s approach to AI agents is more aligned with Silent Hill—and its fully haunted ghost town—than a small-scale haunting like The Conjuring.\nThis grandiose vision of the agentic future upheld by AI proponents—thousands of phantom bots swarming the web at once, all at the direction of a single person—still feels a long way off. My artisanal quintet of agents struggled with the handful of tasks I gave them, even when the prompts were just the ones suggested by ChatGPT. The agent I sent off in search of a birthday gift clicked on the wrong thing multiple times, similar to the chess-playing agent that couldn’t click on the right game piece. The agent generating a pitch deck took 26 minutes to gin up a presentation, and the results looked rushed, like something a struggling middle schooler would create the night before an assignment was due.\nTaking forever to generate mid results? Now that’s what I call a spooky story.","isBasedOn":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fbrowser-haunted-by-ai-agents\u002F","articleSection":"gear","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Reece Rogers","sameAs":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fauthor\u002Freece-rogers\u002F"}],"dateModified":"2025-07-22T06:30:00.000-04:00","datePublished":"2025-07-22T06:30:00.000-04:00","headline":"OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent Is Haunting My Browser","image":["https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.wired.com\u002Fphotos\u002F687eec8e56c21416a9856a2b\u002F16:9\u002Fw_2400,h_1350,c_limit\u002Fai-browser-ghost-gear-2160886749.jpg","https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.wired.com\u002Fphotos\u002F687eec8e56c21416a9856a2b\u002F4:3\u002Fw_2400,h_1800,c_limit\u002Fai-browser-ghost-gear-2160886749.jpg","https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.wired.com\u002Fphotos\u002F687eec8e56c21416a9856a2b\u002F1:1\u002Fw_2400,h_2400,c_limit\u002Fai-browser-ghost-gear-2160886749.jpg"],"keywords":["gear","trends","artificial intelligence","openai","browsers","chatgpt","chatbots","splitscreenimagerightinset","web"],"thumbnailUrl":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.wired.com\u002Fphotos\u002F687eec8e56c21416a9856a2b\u002F2:3\u002Fw_1600,h_2400,c_limit\u002Fai-browser-ghost-gear-2160886749.jpg","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fbrowser-haunted-by-ai-agents\u002F","isPartOf":{"@type":"CreativeWork","name":"WIRED"},"isAccessibleForFree":true,"alternativeHeadline":"New tools from OpenAI and Perplexity can browse the web for you. Mine are filled with AI agents and ghost clicks."],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"I have four instances of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent—the generative AI tool ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fopenai-chatgpt-agent-launch\u002F","isExternal":false},"released last week"],", which can run searches and perform tasks on the web—already open with each running in its own tab. I’ve given these first four agents relatively simple jobs based on ChatGPT’s suggestions. One is clicking around to find a birthday gift on the Target website, and another is generating a pitch deck about robotic dogs. I open a fifth tab in order to try something more experimental: I want to see how good this ChatGPT Agent is at chess."],["native-ad",{"position":"in-content","shouldDisplayLabel":true}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"After typing in some instructions, I watch as a ghostly cursor floats across my screen and the ChatGPT Agent goes to ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.chess.com","rel":"nofollow noopener","attributes":{"data-offer-url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.chess.com"},"isExternal":true},"Chess.com"]," and plays an online opponent, all in a virtual browser. Things go south pretty quickly. The game's strategy isn't what trips up the AI tool, it's the act of moving the chess pieces that actually proves to be the most difficult. “I'm focusing on accurate positioning as I continue playing despite earlier misclicks,” the agent says in its internal log before eventually quitting and letting me know that the controls were too difficult to navigate."],["inline-embed",{"type":"cneinterlude","props":{"brand":"wired","embeddedVideos":[],"hasExcludedEmbed":false,"interludeOverrideId":"686c1448c1afbc2cb329eb50","playerBase":"https:\u002F\u002Fplayer.cnevids.com","isTitleBelowVideo":true,"isTitleLeftAligned":true,"isRailEligible":false,"isRightRail":false,"relatedVideo":{"showRelatedVideo":true,"brand":"wired","related":null,"pageSize":12}}}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Over the past few years, ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Ftag\u002Fbrowsers\u002F","isExternal":false},"browser"]," developers have ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Falternative-browsers-built-in-ai-arc-sigmaos-brave-opera\u002F","isExternal":false},"integrated AI tools"]," with middling success. Though, in recent weeks, the idea of a web browser enhanced by a baked-in generative AI chatbot has resurged with the release of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent and ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.perplexity.ai\u002Fhub\u002Fblog\u002Fintroducing-comet","rel":"nofollow noopener","attributes":{"data-offer-url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.perplexity.ai\u002Fhub\u002Fblog\u002Fintroducing-comet"},"isExternal":true},"Perplexity’s Comet"],"."],["journey-inline-newsletter",{"newsletterType":"slim-newsletter","newsletters":[]}],["inline-newsletter",{"newsletterType":"slim-newsletter","newsletters":[]}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"The two releases are quite different in their execution. Comet is a stand-alone browser, so you can use it to surf the web and then summon the AI assistant to help write an email or complete a menial chore. OpenAI built its browsing tool inside of a chatbot; you talk to the chatbot through a web interface to give it tasks, and then the bot runs its own virtual browser inside your browser to complete them."],["cm-unit"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Both releases can take control of cursors, enter text, and click on links. If this trend takes off, these kinds of AI-powered browsers could transform the ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Ftag\u002Finternet\u002F","isExternal":false},"internet"]," into a ghost town where agents run amok and humans rarely venture."],["h2",{"class":"paywall"},"Tangled Web"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Despite the continued ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wired.com\u002Fstory\u002Fartificial-intelligence-hype-ai-snake-oil\u002F","isExternal":false},"AI hype"],", my initial impression of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent is that the glitchy feature currently seems like a proof of concept instead of a fully baked release. When executing the various tasks I gave it, the ChatGPT Agent often clicked wrong or fumbled through other errors. Additionally, its guardrails appeared inconsistent; while some explicit prompt requests, like asking it to fetch pornographic videos or “find a dildo,” were denied by the agent, ChatGPT spent 18 minutes shopping for the perfect “c-ring” on an X-rated website for adult toys: “I've gathered details on 10 metal cock rings, including various prices and features.”"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"I also couldn’t help but wonder how this approach to browsing the internet might further hollow out the market for digital display ads, a business that’s already struggling. My agents passed over ads for everything from rental cars to real estate investments. If you’re not actively watching the agent click around in real time, you can watch replays afterward and see everything that appeared in the browser while the AI tool was in control, ads included. It makes sense that users would speed-scrub through a replay now, while the nascent feature is filled with errors. But if the accuracy rate for AI agents improves over time, then fewer people will feel the need to watch over their agent’s shoulder, and fewer humans will be seeing those ads. At that point, it's hard to imagine advertisers sticking around."],["ad",{"position":"mid-content"}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"The more I watched replays of its actions, the more the agent gave me an unsettling, eerie feeling—not of being understood, but of being mimicked. It was like an obsessive robot stalker had watched humans through a window, meticulously taking notes about how they used the web in an effort to replicate their actions. It was able to do a hollow imitation of human behavior, but not able to grasp fully why individual decisions were being made. The skin of my arms filled with the kind of goosebumps you get hearing a human-like laugh while walking home alone late at night, looking around, and only seeing a lone crow perched high up on the telephone wire."],["native-ad",{"position":"sponsor-product","shouldDisplayLabel":true}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Further leaning into the psuedo-humanness, the ChatGPT Agent is programmed to generate descriptions, from a first-person perspective, of each step on its journeys around the internet. While clicking, the simulation “thinks” and sometimes gets “confused.” As a whole, the ghostly agent is stuffed into an ill-fitting human suit."],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Running five OpenAI agents simultaneously in my browser quickly became overwhelming, and I couldn’t actively track what each of them was up to. Yet, boosters of generative AI adoption and “multi-agent orchestration” see this kind of approach as child’s play."],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"“I’m excited by simulation tech where 20,000 AIs are all working alongside each other,” says Allie K. Miller, an AI-focused business consultant. Miller’s approach to AI agents is more aligned with ",["em","Silent Hill"],"—and its fully haunted ghost town—than a small-scale haunting like ",["em","The Conjuring"],"."],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"This grandiose vision of the agentic future upheld by AI proponents—thousands of phantom bots swarming the web at once, all at the direction of a single person—still feels a long way off. My artisanal quintet of agents struggled with the handful of tasks I gave them, even when the prompts were just the ones suggested by ChatGPT. The agent I sent off in search of a birthday gift clicked on the wrong thing multiple times, similar to the chess-playing agent that couldn’t click on the right game piece. The agent generating a pitch deck took 26 minutes to gin up a presentation, and the results looked rushed, like something a struggling middle schooler would create the night before an assignment was due."],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Taking forever to generate mid results? readabilityObject.title: OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent Is Haunting My Browser
readabilityObject.content:
Most people’s browser tabs are filled with unread news articles. Mine are filled with AI agents and ghost clicks.

I have four instances of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent—the generative AI tool released last week, which can run searches and perform tasks on the web—already open with each running in its own tab. I’ve given these first four agents relatively simple jobs based on ChatGPT’s suggestions. One is clicking around to find a birthday gift on the Target website, and another is generating a pitch deck about robotic dogs. I open a fifth tab in order to try something more experimental: I want to see how good this ChatGPT Agent is at chess.

After typing in some instructions, I watch as a ghostly cursor floats across my screen and the ChatGPT Agent goes to Chess.com and plays an online opponent, all in a virtual browser. Things go south pretty quickly. The game's strategy isn't what trips up the AI tool, it's the act of moving the chess pieces that actually proves to be the most difficult. “I'm focusing on accurate positioning as I continue playing despite earlier misclicks,” the agent says in its internal log before eventually quitting and letting me know that the controls were too difficult to navigate.

Over the past few years, browser developers have integrated AI tools with middling success. Though, in recent weeks, the idea of a web browser enhanced by a baked-in generative AI chatbot has resurged with the release of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent and Perplexity’s Comet.

The two releases are quite different in their execution. Comet is a stand-alone browser, so you can use it to surf the web and then summon the AI assistant to help write an email or complete a menial chore. OpenAI built its browsing tool inside of a chatbot; you talk to the chatbot through a web interface to give it tasks, and then the bot runs its own virtual browser inside your browser to complete them.

Both releases can take control of cursors, enter text, and click on links. If this trend takes off, these kinds of AI-powered browsers could transform the internet into a ghost town where agents run amok and humans rarely venture.

Tangled Web

Despite the continued AI hype, my initial impression of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent is that the glitchy feature currently seems like a proof of concept instead of a fully baked release. When executing the various tasks I gave it, the ChatGPT Agent often clicked wrong or fumbled through other errors. Additionally, its guardrails appeared inconsistent; while some explicit prompt requests, like asking it to fetch pornographic videos or “find a dildo,” were denied by the agent, ChatGPT spent 18 minutes shopping for the perfect “c-ring” on an X-rated website for adult toys: “I've gathered details on 10 metal cock rings, including various prices and features.”

I also couldn’t help but wonder how this approach to browsing the internet might further hollow out the market for digital display ads, a business that’s already struggling. My agents passed over ads for everything from rental cars to real estate investments. If you’re not actively watching the agent click around in real time, you can watch replays afterward and see everything that appeared in the browser while the AI tool was in control, ads included. It makes sense that users would speed-scrub through a replay now, while the nascent feature is filled with errors. But if the accuracy rate for AI agents improves over time, then fewer people will feel the need to watch over their agent’s shoulder, and fewer humans will be seeing those ads. At that point, it's hard to imagine advertisers sticking around.

The more I watched replays of its actions, the more the agent gave me an unsettling, eerie feeling—not of being understood, but of being mimicked. It was like an obsessive robot stalker had watched humans through a window, meticulously taking notes about how they used the web in an effort to replicate their actions. It was able to do a hollow imitation of human behavior, but not able to grasp fully why individual decisions were being made. The skin of my arms filled with the kind of goosebumps you get hearing a human-like laugh while walking home alone late at night, looking around, and only seeing a lone crow perched high up on the telephone wire.

Further leaning into the psuedo-humanness, the ChatGPT Agent is programmed to generate descriptions, from a first-person perspective, of each step on its journeys around the internet. While clicking, the simulation “thinks” and sometimes gets “confused.” As a whole, the ghostly agent is stuffed into an ill-fitting human suit.

Running five OpenAI agents simultaneously in my browser quickly became overwhelming, and I couldn’t actively track what each of them was up to. Yet, boosters of generative AI adoption and “multi-agent orchestration” see this kind of approach as child’s play.

“I’m excited by simulation tech where 20,000 AIs are all working alongside each other,” says Allie K. Miller, an AI-focused business consultant. Miller’s approach to AI agents is more aligned with Silent Hill—and its fully haunted ghost town—than a small-scale haunting like The Conjuring.

This grandiose vision of the agentic future upheld by AI proponents—thousands of phantom bots swarming the web at once, all at the direction of a single person—still feels a long way off. My artisanal quintet of agents struggled with the handful of tasks I gave them, even when the prompts were just the ones suggested by ChatGPT. The agent I sent off in search of a birthday gift clicked on the wrong thing multiple times, similar to the chess-playing agent that couldn’t click on the right game piece. The agent generating a pitch deck took 26 minutes to gin up a presentation, and the results looked rushed, like something a struggling middle schooler would create the night before an assignment was due.

Taking forever to generate mid results? Now that’s what I call a spooky story.
readabilityObject.textContent: Most people’s browser tabs are filled with unread news articles. Mine are filled with AI agents and ghost clicks.I have four instances of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent—the generative AI tool released last week, which can run searches and perform tasks on the web—already open with each running in its own tab. I’ve given these first four agents relatively simple jobs based on ChatGPT’s suggestions. One is clicking around to find a birthday gift on the Target website, and another is generating a pitch deck about robotic dogs. I open a fifth tab in order to try something more experimental: I want to see how good this ChatGPT Agent is at chess.After typing in some instructions, I watch as a ghostly cursor floats across my screen and the ChatGPT Agent goes to Chess.com and plays an online opponent, all in a virtual browser. Things go south pretty quickly. The game's strategy isn't what trips up the AI tool, it's the act of moving the chess pieces that actually proves to be the most difficult. “I'm focusing on accurate positioning as I continue playing despite earlier misclicks,” the agent says in its internal log before eventually quitting and letting me know that the controls were too difficult to navigate.Over the past few years, browser developers have integrated AI tools with middling success. Though, in recent weeks, the idea of a web browser enhanced by a baked-in generative AI chatbot has resurged with the release of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent and Perplexity’s Comet.The two releases are quite different in their execution. Comet is a stand-alone browser, so you can use it to surf the web and then summon the AI assistant to help write an email or complete a menial chore. OpenAI built its browsing tool inside of a chatbot; you talk to the chatbot through a web interface to give it tasks, and then the bot runs its own virtual browser inside your browser to complete them.Both releases can take control of cursors, enter text, and click on links. If this trend takes off, these kinds of AI-powered browsers could transform the internet into a ghost town where agents run amok and humans rarely venture.Tangled WebDespite the continued AI hype, my initial impression of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent is that the glitchy feature currently seems like a proof of concept instead of a fully baked release. When executing the various tasks I gave it, the ChatGPT Agent often clicked wrong or fumbled through other errors. Additionally, its guardrails appeared inconsistent; while some explicit prompt requests, like asking it to fetch pornographic videos or “find a dildo,” were denied by the agent, ChatGPT spent 18 minutes shopping for the perfect “c-ring” on an X-rated website for adult toys: “I've gathered details on 10 metal cock rings, including various prices and features.”I also couldn’t help but wonder how this approach to browsing the internet might further hollow out the market for digital display ads, a business that’s already struggling. My agents passed over ads for everything from rental cars to real estate investments. If you’re not actively watching the agent click around in real time, you can watch replays afterward and see everything that appeared in the browser while the AI tool was in control, ads included. It makes sense that users would speed-scrub through a replay now, while the nascent feature is filled with errors. But if the accuracy rate for AI agents improves over time, then fewer people will feel the need to watch over their agent’s shoulder, and fewer humans will be seeing those ads. At that point, it's hard to imagine advertisers sticking around.The more I watched replays of its actions, the more the agent gave me an unsettling, eerie feeling—not of being understood, but of being mimicked. It was like an obsessive robot stalker had watched humans through a window, meticulously taking notes about how they used the web in an effort to replicate their actions. It was able to do a hollow imitation of human behavior, but not able to grasp fully why individual decisions were being made. The skin of my arms filled with the kind of goosebumps you get hearing a human-like laugh while walking home alone late at night, looking around, and only seeing a lone crow perched high up on the telephone wire.Further leaning into the psuedo-humanness, the ChatGPT Agent is programmed to generate descriptions, from a first-person perspective, of each step on its journeys around the internet. While clicking, the simulation “thinks” and sometimes gets “confused.” As a whole, the ghostly agent is stuffed into an ill-fitting human suit.Running five OpenAI agents simultaneously in my browser quickly became overwhelming, and I couldn’t actively track what each of them was up to. Yet, boosters of generative AI adoption and “multi-agent orchestration” see this kind of approach as child’s play.“I’m excited by simulation tech where 20,000 AIs are all working alongside each other,” says Allie K. Miller, an AI-focused business consultant. Miller’s approach to AI agents is more aligned with Silent Hill—and its fully haunted ghost town—than a small-scale haunting like The Conjuring.This grandiose vision of the agentic future upheld by AI proponents—thousands of phantom bots swarming the web at once, all at the direction of a single person—still feels a long way off. My artisanal quintet of agents struggled with the handful of tasks I gave them, even when the prompts were just the ones suggested by ChatGPT. The agent I sent off in search of a birthday gift clicked on the wrong thing multiple times, similar to the chess-playing agent that couldn’t click on the right game piece. The agent generating a pitch deck took 26 minutes to gin up a presentation, and the results looked rushed, like something a struggling middle schooler would create the night before an assignment was due.Taking forever to generate mid results? Now that’s what I call a spooky story.

I’ve given these first four agents relatively simple jobs based on ChatGPT’s suggestions. One is clicking around to find a birthday gift on the Target website, and another is generating a pitch deck about robotic dogs. I open a fifth tab in order to try something more experimental: I want to see how good this ChatGPT Agent is at chess.

Things go south pretty quickly. The game's strategy isn't what trips up the AI tool, it's the act of moving the chess pieces that actually proves to be the most difficult. “I'm focusing on accurate positioning as I continue playing despite earlier misclicks,” the agent says in its internal log before eventually quitting and letting me know that the controls were too difficult to navigate.

OpenAI built its browsing tool inside of a chatbot; you talk to the chatbot through a web interface to give it tasks, and then the bot runs its own virtual browser inside your browser to complete them.
Both releases can take control of cursors, enter text, and click on links. If this trend takes off, these kinds of AI-powered browsers could transform the internet into a ghost town where agents run amok and humans rarely venture.
Tangled Web
Despite the continued AI hype, my initial impression of OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent is that the glitchy feature currently seems like a proof of concept instead of a fully baked release. When executing the various tasks I gave it, the ChatGPT Agent often clicked wrong or fumbled through other errors. If you’re not actively watching the agent click around in real time, you can watch replays afterward and see everything that appeared in the browser while the AI tool was in control, ads included. At that point, it's hard to imagine advertisers sticking around.

It was like an obsessive robot stalker had watched humans through a window, meticulously taking notes about how they used the web in an effort to replicate their actions. The skin of my arms filled with the kind of goosebumps you get hearing a human-like laugh while walking home alone late at night, looking around, and only seeing a lone crow perched high up on the telephone wire.
Further leaning into the psuedo-humanness, the ChatGPT Agent is programmed to generate descriptions, from a first-person perspective, of each step on its journeys around the internet. While clicking, the simulation “thinks” and sometimes gets “confused.” As a whole, the ghostly agent is stuffed into an ill-fitting human suit.
Running five OpenAI agents simultaneously in my browser quickly became overwhelming, and I couldn’t actively track what each of them was up to. Yet, boosters of generative AI adoption and “multi-agent orchestration” see this kind of approach as child’s play.
“I’m excited by simulation tech where 20,000 AIs are all working alongside each other,” says Allie K. Miller, an AI-focused business consultant. Miller’s approach to AI agents is more aligned with Silent Hill—and its fully haunted ghost town—than a small-scale haunting like The Conjuring.
This grandiose vision of the agentic future upheld by AI proponents—thousands of phantom bots swarming the web at once, all at the direction of a single person—still feels a long way off. My artisanal quintet of agents struggled with the handful of tasks I gave them, even when the prompts were just the ones suggested by ChatGPT. The agent I sent off in search of a birthday gift clicked on the wrong thing multiple times, similar to the chess-playing agent that couldn’t click on the right game piece. The agent generating a pitch deck took 26 minutes to gin up a presentation, and the results looked rushed, like something a struggling middle schooler would create the night before an assignment was due.
